data.title: Add build fix from #2435
Error when building latest version on OSX
data.body:
I could build it without issue on my MBA that run OSX 10.10 but it fails on an iMac with OSX 10.9.4 + XCode up to date.
Here's the log of the `script/build` task: 

```
Node: v0.11.13
npm: v1.4.9
Installing build modules...
npm WARN engine coffee-script-redux@2.0.0-beta8: wanted: {"node":"0.8.x || 0.10.x"} (current: {"node":"v0.11.13","npm":"1.4.9"})
npm WARN engine prettyjson@0.8.1: wanted: {"node":">= 0.6.0 < 0.11.0"} (current: {"node":"v0.11.13","npm":"1.4.9"})
npm WARN engine prettyjson@0.8.1: wanted: {"node":">= 0.6.0 < 0.11.0"} (current: {"node":"v0.11.13","npm":"1.4.9"})
Installing apm...
npm WARN package.json github-url-from-git@1.1.1 No repository field.
dyld: lazy symbol binding failed: Symbol not found: _node_module_register
  Referenced from: /Users/cedric/github/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/keytar/build/Release/keytar.node
  Expected in: dynamic lookup

dyld: Symbol not found: _node_module_register
  Referenced from: /Users/cedric/github/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/keytar/build/Release/keytar.node
  Expected in: dynamic lookup

/Users/cedric/github/atom/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin/apm: line 40: 69330 Trace/BPT trap: 5       "$binDir/$nodeBin" --harmony_collections "$binDir/../lib/cli.js" "$@"
```

I also tried to build it on node 0.10 but when running `npm install` I get: 

```
../src/scrollbar-style-observer-mac.mm:42:3: error: no matching function for call to
      'uv_async_init'
  uv_async_init(loop, &async, asyncSendHandler);
  ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
/Users/cedric/.node-gyp/0.10.21/deps/uv/include/uv.h:1186:15: note: candidate function not
      viable: no known conversion from 'void (uv_async_t *)' to 'uv_async_cb' (aka
      'void (*)(uv_async_t *, int)') for 3rd argument
UV_EXTERN int uv_async_init(uv_loop_t*, uv_async_t* async,
              ^
1 error generated.
make: *** [Release/obj.target/scrollbar-style-observer/src/scrollbar-style-observer-mac.o] Error 1
gyp ERR! build error
gyp ERR! stack Error: `make` failed with exit code: 2
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.onExit (/Users/cedric/.nvm/v0.10.21/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/build.js:267:23)
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:98:17)
gyp ERR! stack     at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (child_process.js:789:12)
gyp ERR! System Darwin 13.3.0
gyp ERR! command "node" "/Users/cedric/.nvm/v0.10.21/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "rebuild"
gyp ERR! cwd /Users/cedric/github/atom/node_modules/scrollbar-style
gyp ERR! node -v v0.10.21
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v0.10.10
gyp ERR! not ok
npm ERR! weird error 1
```

And then forcing a build after that gave the same error as with node v0.11.13.

Is there's something I missed regarding my system configuration.

data.title: Revert unsaved changes when checking out HEAD
data.body:
Fix #2909.

Test Plan:
- Edited a file. Ran `editor:checkout-head-revision` and it reverted.
- Edited a file, saved it, then edited again. Running
  `editor:checkout-head-revision` reverts the lot.
- Ran undo afterwards and the edits come back, so that still works.

data.title: Missing menu bar on KDE if using icon-tasks plasmoid
data.body:
Related to issue #3114 

Using KDE 4.13.2, on Ubuntu 14.04 64 bit.
![snapshot1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/3807925/7f4b555a-1c6f-11e4-824b-3c878f3343f4.png)
Tagged version 1.120.0 displays menus properly using the exact same setup:
![snapshot1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/3807924/7bea8dc2-1c6f-11e4-96eb-452017505684.png)

After commit 4a7e98e398422a5783d26d7a8944ec6e405bce53 , menus won't show in KDE4 if using the "Icons-only task manager" plasmoid.
This task manager identifies itself as an Unity component (as seen in here http://projects.kde.org/projects/kde/kdeplasma-addons/repository/revisions/master/entry/applets/icontasks/unity.cpp) for compatibility purposes, such as displaying quicklists and counters. It doesn't however, interact with appmenus in any way. And it doesn't seem to request them either. (unity.cpp lines 34 to 36).
My KDE desktop is configured to show all menus inside applications, so there's no global menubar active. So, despite the menus being exported, they are never displayed anywhere. It appears to be mistakenly confusing the plasmoid's presence (in DBUS perhaps?) as a global menu.

Disabling Unity support in the plasmoid does allow Atom to show menus normally, as illustrated here.
![snapshot1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/3807946/f3796b74-1c6f-11e4-9f55-3a8d531ba564.png)

Any way to attempt to prevent Atom from exporting its menus (blacklisting in Unity's dconf, environment variables, etc) doesn't seem to prevent the disabling of the normal menu.

Please let me know if any other information is required.

data.title: Syntax highlighting when using "{" or "}" in string
data.body:
Brackets inside of strings are given the same level of priority as code brackets, so having the cursor set before

Here would be an example in Golang.  I will bold-italics the brackets to show what it looks like.

x := 0
if x == 0 {
fmt.Println("**_{**_")
**_}**_

Atom should preferably be highlighting (underlining) the open bracket in 'if x == 0 {' rather than in 'fmt.Println("{")'.  This just makes it a little bit harder to find where the brackets begin or end when sifting through code.  Not a big problem, but not ideal.

data.title: App name in windows
data.body:
There are a number of places in windows where apps are listed. For some bizarre reason Atom is listed as "The Hackable Editor" instead of "Atom". You have to go down to the T part of the list. For a long time I thought Atom wasn't available in app lists. I know of no other app that doesn't use its name for this. It's a nuisance.

![hackable](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/811455/3803928/2ce6bfe2-1c20-11e4-95d2-8cd9fb1155ed.jpg)

data.title: Move tabs into titlebar (like FF/Chrome)
data.body:
Please move the tabs into the titlebar like firefox or chrome does. This means less wasted space on screen.
Also referencing #2914 since these two go well together.

data.title: All inputs in the settings view have scrollbars
data.body:
Not sure if this is an atom issue or a settings-view one so apologies if this is in the wrong place. Looks like they only have about 2px of scroll range.

Ubuntu 12.04, happens regardless of themes or packages (still happens with `atom --safe`)

![screenshot from 2014-08-04 10 01 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/120506/3795097/cd636296-1bb6-11e4-90a9-e43d2f67690a.png)

data.title: Add some sub-options for "Show Invisibles"
data.body:
I think the purpose of "show invisibles" is to help us distinguish between:
Tabs and spaces
Windows line-ending and Unix line-ending

But a large number of "dot" spaces in the left side will look very ugly! I suggest adding some sub-options to control the visibility of:
space character
tab character
LF character
CR character

So, if someone dislike spaces shown, he can turn it off. He can still distinguish spaces from tabs, because tab is on. If someone mostly do coding in Unix line-ending, but want to recognize other developer's Windows line-ending file, he can turn LF off and keep CR on.

data.title: Add an option to disable "quick jump" between indents
data.body:
In Atom, it's not possible to begin or end a selection at the midpoint of an indent, because the caret can't be jumped there. But as a text editor, I think it should be able to do anything a normal text editor can do, regardless of whether it's meaningful or not.

My suggestion: leave the default "as is", but add an option to disable the "quick jump".

data.title: Load default theme when running in Safe Mode
data.body:
This is what I see when I launch in safe mode ...

![screen shot 2014-08-03 at 7 42 25 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038121/3792706/02301e28-1b81-11e4-8469-17983f7eb281.png)

Because I use custom themes that are in the `~/.atom/packages` directory, all style information is lost when I launch in Safe Mode ... meaning I need to change my configuration when I need to use Safe Mode and then change it back when I'm done.

It would be much nicer if Atom would do this for me :grinning:

data.title: Atom shouldn't open folders in new windows when it's just been launched
data.body:
I installed Atom on both Windows 7 (64-bit) and Linux (Ubuntu 13.10 amd64) using the [published instructions](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/windows.md).

If I launch Atom from the Start menu (Windows) or the desktop launcher (Linux) I start with a completely empty editor window containing a handy tip. If I then use `File > Open Folder...` and open some project I'm working on, it opens in a new window.

This means I now have two windows: the one for the project I really want to work on, and a useless empty one that I have to close. In fact, the first window launched won't _ever_ do anything useful — no matter what you open from it, it will show up in a new window.

It would be nice if Atom didn't do this — if it could figure out that it's in a "just-launched" state and do the right thing.

(Note that this is _not_ about Atom _always_ opening non-sibling files in new windows. It's purely about that first open action from a desktop-file-launched window.)

data.title: Add OS X proxy icon to title bar
data.body:
![image](http://i.imgur.com/0WCzYA7.gif)

Fixes #1891.

Test Plan:
- Opened Atom window in directory, verified directory icon shows up
- Opened a file and verified icon changed
- Right clicked icon, verified menu appears
- Drag file to terminal and it pastes the file path (yay)
- Opened a new Atom window and opened some files in that to make sure that
  it didn't change the original window

I didn't add any specs for this - advice welcome here. I also haven't tested
on Windows or Linux but it looks like `setRepresentedFilename` is a noop on
those platforms.

data.title: Make `editor:checkout-head-revision` redoable
data.body:
Related to #3168 

Given that the standard keyboard mapping on all platforms is a variation on Undo, this command should affect the Undo stack as an Undo command _not_ like a regular command. To illustrate:
1. Executing the command  should revert the contents of the file to the last committed contents in Git
2. Executing Undo again should do nothing
3. Executing Redo should reset the contents of the file to where it was before the `editor:checkout-head-revision` command was executed

data.title: Add confirmation dialog to checkoutHead
data.body:
There have been a few reports of files mysteriously going back to the last version in the tree. My theory is that it is because of people fat-fingering the Undo command because the default keyboard mapping is too similar. This will at least prevent most accidental data loss.

Fixes atom/atom#3168

data.title: Default keyboard mapping for Checkout Head Revision problematic
data.body:
The default keyboard mapping for `editor:checkout-head-revision` is <kbd>Cmd+Alt+Z</kbd> or <kbd>Ctrl+Alt+Z</kbd> on Windows/Linux. This is pretty easy to fat-finger and there is no confirmation dialog. Also, the Redo command doesn't restore what was lost ... but Undo does ... which is confusing when this command is accidentally triggered.

We should probably display a confirmation dialog for this command to be certain it is what the user wants and since data loss (or perceived data loss) can result.

See Discuss topics: 
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/sometimes-s-or-z-does-buu-buu/11186?u=leedohm
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/a-seriously-nasty-problem/11286
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/undo-redo-broken/10658
- https://discuss.atom.io/t/undo-defect-undo-make-my-file-back-to-status-when-i-open-it/10512

data.title: Fix error when cmd+click is executed over an already highlighted region
'post' files being created on window reload
data.body:
Weird bug, I suspect `atom-shell` but since I'm not sure I post it here. Lately I see an immense amount of weird "post" files (see screenshot):

![screenshot from 2014-08-03 14 48 56](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5219415/3791095/5cd5ce08-1b28-11e4-97bc-03bb73ef31ee.png)

Here's what I do to provoke the bug (does not work instantly, but after one or two tries)
- Open atom (normal mode) on project im working on (atom package).
- Open `atom --dev` on a test repository.
- Change things in test repository, do not save the files.
- Window reload on the `atom --dev` instance, do not save the files.
- With a little bit of luck a `post` file appears in the **other atom instance's project folder** (the one running in normal mode).
- The `post` files are always empty.

This is somehow ... Weird?

**System:** `arch 3.15.8-1-ARCH x86_64 GNU/Linux`

I made a video in `safe` mode to show what I mean. The hotkey I am using to refresh the window is `Ctrl-Alt-R` which triggers triggers `window:reload`

[video@youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1eSNcNYAQg&hd=1)

data.title: Broken links in API Docs
data.body:
Clicking a "Source" link in the [API](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.120.0/api/) leads to a 404.  Biscotto generates links like:

```
https://github.com/atom/atom//blob/v0.120.0/src/task.coffee#L48
```

When it should be

```
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v0.120.0/src/task.coffee#L48
```

The repo name has an extra slash at the end.  I don't think it is a bug in biscotto, rather a bug in building the api docs, so I added it here.

data.title: Editor settings should be contextual to scope
data.body: Editor settings like "soft tabs", "tab length", "preferred line length" should be dependent on scope just like keybindings are. For example, we use 80 character line length for Python, but no limit for HTML. We indent Python at 4 spaces but CSS at 2. Etc.

data.title: Make indent guides indicate changing indentation earlier
data.body:
The current indent-guides _lazily_ indicate when the indentation level changes. By "lazy", I mean that the indentation guides keep showing up until a line appears with different content. Example of lazy indentation guides:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4427/3789451/b265f116-1aa3-11e4-91eb-123e73337590.png)

Contrast this to _eager_ indentation guides, which disappear as soon as they can:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4427/3789447/a5430e06-1aa3-11e4-8665-55b190872467.png)

Lazy indentation guides work well in curly-brace languages because there is content on the line to indicate when a block finishes. However, in CoffeeScript and Python, they don't work well because there is no closing brace, and we end up with confusing guides that don't seem to match up with blocks.

This issue is asking that Atom indentation guides are changed from lazy to eager. Another way of describing it is to change the indentation guides so that they end where the closing brace would be in a curly-brace language.

data.title: Open too many tabs freezes the editor
data.body:
Blank tabs issue.

Open a new atom window and create some empty tabs, let's say 8, result: the editor freezes and it never starts to work again.

Additionally: I started off with a new atom installation (no extra packages) and i tried again: same result.

Version: 0.120.0
Node: v0.10.29
OS: Mavericks 10.9.4.

Thank you!

data.title: Atom erasing the content of files when there is not enough disk space
data.body:
I have a hard time replicating this issue since it will require me filling up the disk again, but in a nutshell the problem is that when I edit a file in Atom, if the disk space is not enough to save it, I find that the file content is erased. 

This happened to me more than once (yeah I need more Gbs of disk space) so I can certify that it is Atom the one causing the issue. The issue appears whenever I edit the file, not when I just open it. The problem is not that Atom is not being able to save the file (that would make sense if there is no disk space available), the problem is that Atom _removes all the content_, and of course I'm afterwards not able to recover it.

I have no clue of why may this be happening

data.title: Language translations
data.body: Language translations, for those with poor English skills or like using software in their language. Could be done with packages.

data.title: Can't build on OS X
data.body:
Seems that NPM is having a problem when trying to build Atom. I have filed a bug at npm/npm#5864 and am waiting for a response there.

Anyone else have this problem or has had this problem before? If so, how did you fix it?
